description: From French caresse, from Italian carezza (“dear”), from Latin cārus (“dear”), from Proto-Indo-European *keh₂-, akin to Sanskrit काम (kāma, “love”). Doublet of karezza.

entries.meaning: An act of endearment; any act or expression of affection; an embracing, or touching, with tenderness. [from 1640s]

verbs.description: caress (third-person singular simple present caresses, present participle caressing, simple past and past participle caressed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To touch or kiss lovingly; to fondle.
examples: Synonyms: hold, soothe, stroke, kiss; see also Thesaurus:fondle, Thesaurus:kiss
She loves being caressed by her boyfriend.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To affect as if with a caress.
examples: The love and anguish in his voice caressed my mind and soul.
